node.text: From @nrdc_org | The biggest sources of air pollution in the U.S. are coal-fired power plants, industrial facilities, and cars and trucks that are running on fossil fuels. These dirty energy sources are harming public health and driving #climatechange.

node.title: Air Pollution 101: Our Health and Climate at Risk

node.text: From @cnnclimate | Dams that beavers build can reduce flooding and drought, increase biodiversity, and lower pollution. They were hunted to extinction across Europe for their pelts -- but now they're being reintroduced into the wild in England, and their impact is remarkable.

node.title: How reintroducing beavers into the wild transforms ecosystems

node.text:
Ghana’s #Atewa Forest is a special place, not only because of the wildlife it safeguards, but because of the many communities that depend on it for clean air and water, medicine, climate regulation, and natural beauty. But bauxite mining for aluminium could leave the forest stripped and devoid of life. 

Global manufacturing companies @bmwgroup, @tetrapak and @schueco have signaled their concerns over the use of bauxite sourced from Atewa Forest for aluminium. Join us and our partners in calling on Ghana’s government to #SaveAtewaForest by designating it a national forest! 

Sign the @Change.org petition ----> Link in bio 

#KeyBiodiversityAreas  #KBA  #AtewaTillEternity  #SaveAtewa4Water  #Atewa4NationalPark

node.text:
"As a scientist, I was surprised to find that race had the strongest relationship to the length of time people had to live with drinking water violations. But as a Black woman, I was not surprised at all." - @nrdc_org scientist Kristi Pullen Fedinick

Safe drinking water is a human right. *No one should have to wonder about the safety of their water every time they turn on their tap.* Yet EPA data confirms that there is still unequal access to safe drinking water, based most strongly on race. This data echoes the lived experience that communities of color and low-income people across the country have been calling attention to for years.

In this video, Elizabeth Martinez of @LideresCampesinas—and a resident of Kern County, California—talks about the impacts of living in a county with a long history of violations of the Safe Drinking Water Act. Michele Roberts of the Environmental Justice Health Alliance and NRDC scientist Kristi Pullen Fedinick highlight their analysis of EPA data that shows why local, state and federal lawmakers need to fix this urgent problem now. Read their full report: http://on.nrdc.org/3mJet1w And take action! Send a message to the new #BidenHarris administration, urging them to fix our federal drinking water law and ensure safe drinking water conditions for all! ➡️ http://on.nrdc.org/2nWj2gx
#environmentaljustice #drinkingwater #safedrinkingwater #publichealth

node.title: From @nrdc_org: Safe Drinking Water Is a Right

node.text: Global leaders have set targets to reach net zero emissions by the second half of this century. That means putting the same amount of greenhouse gases into the air as we take out. Here are five ways we can help towards that individually.

node.title: From @bbcnews: How to cut your carbon footprint

node.text:
#Regram from @leonardodicaprio: @virunganationalpark is home to more species of birds, reptiles and mammals than any other protected area in Africa.

In 2013, I had the honor of meeting and supporting Virunga’s courageous team in their fight against illegal oil drilling.

Our partners at @global_wildlife_conservation are currently raising money for the Virunga Emergency Fund and will match up to $33k in donations until tomorrow at 7am ET.

If you are able to support, please see the link in my bio. ⬆️

#ChristmasChallenge20 #Virunga #VirungaNationalPark

node.text: From @unep: A new #WildForLife Journey takes you through the ultimate #NatureBasedSolution: peatlands. They cover just 3% of the planet’s surface but they store twice as much carbon as all the world’s forests! Link in @unep’s bio for more from their #WildForLife series.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Earth Alliance on July 30, 2021. May be an image of big cat and outdoors.

node.text:
From @davidyarrow: The Jungle Book Stories for #GlobalTigerDay

There were only about 1,700 Royal Bengal Tigers left in India at the time this photograph was taken in 2013 – a frightening decline from the estimated 100,000 during the Raj. Therefore, to find a father and son bathing in the same pool in the jungle was statistically unlikely.

The positioning of the animals relative to the surroundings or each other is a matter of luck. Over time, luck will average out, but the placement of the adult tiger’s left ear covering his son’s right eye enhances a picture which evokes jungle book stories.

I like the lone eye to the right – even though it’s outside my focal plane, it ironically grabs our focused eyes.

node.text:
Via @paulhiltonphoto | A prominent Australian businessman, Clive Palmer, owns Central Queensland Coal and wants to build a colossal coal mine just 10 km from the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage Area.

Government-appointed scientists have warned of “significant and irreversible damage” to precious Reef ecosystems if this reckless coal mine goes ahead, and the QLD Department of Environment and Science has found the project “not suitable” to proceed.

Approving any new coal mines in the middle of a climate crisis that’s caused marine heatwaves to wreak havoc on our Reef and oceans is unacceptable. Approving an open cut coal mine 10 km from the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage Area would be unforgivable.

Add your voice today to urge federal environment minister Sussan Ley to listen to the scientific experts and say no to this damaging project. Link in @paulhiltonphoto’s bio.

#climatecrisis #earthtreeimages

node.text:
The Vjosa River, an almost 260-kilometer stretch of crystal-clear water which flows unchecked from the mountains in Greece through Albania into the Adriatic Sea and sustains thousands of different species, faces an uncertain future. Albanian activists and international organizations have been campaigning to make the Vjosa Europe’s first wild river national park. Status as a national park would protect it from dams and the latest threat - that emerged just before the Albanian federal elections - drilling for oil and gas. 

More at the link in bio.

#VjosaNationalParkNow

node.text:
Comprising over 70% of our Planet and absorbing the majority of excess heat and carbon dioxide from human activities, the ocean is our biggest asset to ensure a healthy future. Scientists have called for protecting at least 30% of the global ocean through a network of highly and fully protected marine areas to keep our ocean healthy and stave off the worst impacts of the climate crisis.

At last week’s Leaders Climate Summit, the President of Chile, @sebastianpinerae put the ocean on center stage in global efforts to address the climate crisis. President Piñera announced Chile will advance a proposal to fully protect an area of the #highseas in the Southeastern Pacific known as the Nazca Ridge. This is exactly the kind of leadership we need to safeguard our ocean and our Planet in the face of the climate crisis. This announcement also builds on Chile’s efforts to secure a new global ocean protection target at the upcoming Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) meeting to protect at least 30% of the global ocean by 2030 through a network of highly and fully protected marine areas. #30x30

The Nazca Ridge MPA will provide refuge to highly migratory species like endangered sea turtles, whales and sharks that navigate up and down the Pacific using underwater sea mountains. The MPA will be the first of its kind, managed by the soon to be finalized United Nations High Seas Treaty and will require international cooperation to ensure it offers protections to all biodiversity of the area.

Read more about it via the link in bio.

@theblueleaders @mission_blue @nrdc_org @unbiodiversity @donabertarelli

Photo Credit: @max_bello

node.text:
The Caribbean island of St. Vincent is suffering a series of explosive volcanic eruptions that has forced 20,000 people out of their homes, destroyed large tracts of forest, and sent toxic ash raining down across the island. The St. Vincent & the Grenadines Forestry Department needs your help as they work tirelessly to clear fallen trees, restore the nation’s water and power supplies and rescue wild animals. 
📢 Help these brave men and women by clicking the link in @faunafloraint’s bio. 
📸: Nadia Huggins

node.text:
From @cnnclimate | What do North Carolina's red wolves, the Eurasian lynx and Przewalski's horse have in common? All of them went extinct in the wild — and all of them came back, thanks to conservation scientists. Translocation and captive breeding was used to re-establish animal populations. Then the animals were reintroduced to their native territories. It can be a double win: helping to restore degraded ecosystems, as well as increasing population numbers.

(📸: Genya Savilov/AFP via Getty Images, Salwan Georges/The Washington Post via Getty Images, Devon Wildlife Trust, Guam Department of Agriculture, WildArk/Aussie Ark, Nature Picture Library/Alamy, John Pierce Owner PhotoSport Int/Shutterstock)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Earth Alliance on April 20, 2021. May be an image of ocean, nature and beach.

node.text:
Via @unep | 🌊Oceans are facing unprecedented threats as a result of human activity.⠀

🔵8️⃣ million tonnes of plastic 🥤🧃end up in oceans every year⠀
🔵Climate change is damaging coral reefs and other key ecosystems⠀
🔵Overfishing 🎣 is threatening the stability of fish stocks 🐟🐟⠀
🔵Nearly 8️⃣0️⃣% of the world's wastewater is discharged without treatment⠀

Let’s continue our work #ForNature and #BeatPollution for #CleanSeas

From @nrdc_org | Carbon-capturing forests, soils, oceans, and freshwater systems are some of our most effective tools in fighting climate change. 🌲 We need to embrace natural climate solutions by protecting at least 30 percent of our lands and waters by 2030—following the lead of Indigenous people who’ve done this for millennia. 🌊 

🎨: @alexbowman

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Earth Alliance on April 14, 2021. May be an image of animal and nature.

node.text:
From @thewcs | Vehicle collisions are a growing threat to primates living in increasingly fragmented habitats crisscrossed by roads. Now, new research shows speedbumps can protect one of Africa's rarest primates.

Endangered Zanzibar red colobus are found only in the Zanzibar archipelago. Reliant on Unguja Island’s forests for their survival, around half of the population is found in Jozani-Chwaka Bay National Park.

Historic data from there showed that one colobus was killed on average every 2-3 weeks by traffic. After speedbumps were installed, that was cut to one every six weeks, says new research co-authored by @thewcs.

Read more via their bio.

#africa #tanzania #zanzibar #wildlifecollisions #speedbump #nationalpark #conservation #raremonkey #monkey #monkeys

Photo by Earth Alliance on April 14, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'NEW RESEARCH SHOWS THAT SPEEDBUMPS'.

Photo by Earth Alliance on April 14, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'CAN SAVE RARE ZANZIBAR RED COLOBUS Data from the road traversing Zanzibar's Jozani-Chwaka Bay National park shows that one colobus was killed on average every 2 to 3 weeks by traffic. After speedbumps were installed, this reduced to 1 every 6 weeks. This demonstrates the value of speedbumpsin reducing wildlife roadkill and shows the need for more!'.
